courses.title: CS 1110 - Introduction to Computing: A Design and Development Perspective
courses.description: CS 1110 introduces programming and problem solving using Python. It emphasizes software development principles, style, and testing. The course is designed for students with no prior programming experience. Assumes basic high school mathematics.

courses.title: CS 1112 - Introduction to Computing: An Engineering and Science Perspective
courses.prereqs: None, but knowledge of calculus is assumed
courses.description: CS 1112 emphasizes the systematic development of algorithms and programs using Python. The course is designed for students with some knowledge of calculus. Programming experience is not required.

courses.title: CS 2110 - Object-Oriented Programming and Data Structures
topics: Data structures (e.g., lists, trees, hash tables)
courses.description: CS 2110 focuses on intermediate programming in Java and introduces software engineering concepts. Students are expected to implement nontrivial Java programs and analyze their complexity.

courses.title: CS 2800 - Mathematical Foundations of Computing
courses.description: CS 2800 covers the mathematics that underpins computer science. These concepts are explored in the context of applications to various areas of computer science.

courses.title: CS 3110 - Data Structures and Functional Programming
courses.description: CS 3110 is an advanced programming course that emphasizes functional programming techniques and data structures.

courses.title: CS 3410 - Computer System Organization and Programming
courses.description: CS 3410 introduces computer organization, systems programming, and the hardware/software interface.

courses.title: CS 3700 - Foundations of AI Reasoning and Decision-Making
courses.description: CS 3700 introduces major topics in artificial intelligence, including heuristic search, game-playing, knowledge representation and reasoning, planning, and reinforcement learning.

courses.title: CS 3780 - Introduction to Machine Learning
courses.description: CS 3780 provides an introduction to machine learning, focusing on supervised learning and its theoretical foundations.

courses.title: CS 4110 - [Programming Languages and Logics]
courses.description: CS 4110 is an introduction to the theory, design, and implementation of programming languages.

courses.title: CS 4120 - Introduction to Compilers
topics: Specification and implementation of modern compilers
Compile-time and run-time support for programming languages
courses.description: CS 4120 introduces the specification and implementation of modern compilers. Students will build a working compiler for an object-oriented language.

courses.title: CS 4121 - Practicum in Compilers
topics: Practical implementation of a compiler for an object-oriented language
courses.description: CS 4121 is a practicum course where students will build a working compiler for an object-oriented language.

courses.title: CS 4320 - Introduction to Database Systems
topics: Modern database and data storage systems
Recovery in relational and non-relational data storage systems
courses.description: CS 4320 provides an introduction to modern database and data storage systems.

courses.title: CS 4321 - Practicum in Database Systems
topics: Practical implementation of database systems in Java
courses.description: CS 4321 is a practicum course where students build part of a database system in Java.

courses.title: CS 4410 - Operating Systems
courses.description: CS 4410 introduces the design of systems programs, with an emphasis on multiprogrammed operating systems.

courses.title: CS 4411 - Practicum in Operating Systems
topics: Practical implementation of an operating system kernel
courses.description: CS 4411 studies the practical aspects of operating systems through the design and implementation of an operating system kernel.

courses.title: CS 4414 - Systems Programming
topics: Security abstractions for isolation and authorization
courses.description: CS 4414 exposes students to programming applications at the systems level and to the operating-systems abstractions that these applications depend on.
